title.native: 宇宙ショーへようこそ

description:
A tiny mountain village in a remote woodland region. Five primary school kids have come together in this idyllic spot in order to spend their summer holidays at a camp. At first the children enjoy carefree days amidst unspoiled nature far away from adult supervision. But their life changes dramatically when they come across what they believe to be a small dog, badly in need of help. The creature – known as Pochi – turns out not to be a dog at all but an alien on an important mission.

It seems there is a mysterious substance on earth that is coveted throughout the universe. Pochi had almost found it but was so badly injured during a fight that he had to give up his search. Thanks to the children's help, the alien survives – and decides to reward them generously. “Where would you most like to travel?” is the question Pochi puts to his rescuers. Their answer is prompt, if vague:
“As far as possible!” Pochi suggests they try the moon first of all, and so, the alien whisks away the kids to the satellite next door. This marks the beginning of an absolutely amazing adventure.

During the course of their travels they discover that the substance coveted throughout the universe is in fact also integral to Japanese cuisine – and it just so happens that one of the kids has some of this mysterious substance in his pocket.

(Source: Berlinale.de)

tags.name: Space
tags.description: Partly or completely set in outer space.

tags.name: Primarily Child Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of characters below a high school age.

tags.name: Urban Fantasy
tags.description: Set in a world similar to the real world, but with the existence of magic or other supernatural elements.

tags.name: Rural
tags.description: Partly or completely set in the countryside.

tags.name: Travel
tags.description: Centers around character(s) moving between places a significant distance apart.

tags.name: Tomboy
tags.description: Features a girl who exhibits characteristics or behaviors considered in many cultures to be typical of boys.

tags.name: Animals
tags.description: Prominently features animal characters in a leading role.

title.native: 宇宙ショーへようこそ

node.description:
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/masaakiyuasa)

An acclaimed anime director known for his wild, freeform style. 

After graduating from the Kyushu Sangyo University's Faculty of Arts in 1987 he joined studio [Ajia-do](https://anilist.co/studio/30/Ajiado), initially as in-betweener but rapidly moving to key animation. 

In the first part of his career Yuasa established himself as an idiosyncratic creator while working on several child friendly anime, such as [Chibi Maruko-chan](https://anilist.co/anime/951/Chibi-Marukochan/) and [Doraemon](https://anilist.co/anime/2677/Doraemon-Nobitas-Animal-Planet/), but especially on [Crayon Shin-chan](https://anilist.co/anime/966/Shin-Chan/), a project he was involved with for most of the '90s. 

One of his breakthrough roles in this period was his participation on the second part of [The Hakkenden](https://anilist.co/anime/12715/The-Hakkenden-Legend-of-the-Dog-Warriors-Part-2/), working as animation director under [Shinya Oohira](https://anilist.co/staff/103893/Shinya-Oohira)'s direction. This OVA was an important outing of the '90s, uniting many veteran artists and talented newcomers. 

He debuted as director on [Mind Game](https://anilist.co/anime/875/Mind-Game/), an abstract piece combining animation and live-action footage, winning the 2004 Japan Media Arts Festival (overcoming even Hayao Miyazaki's [Howl's Moving Castle](https://anilist.co/anime/431/Howls-Moving-Castle/)), and earning [Yoshiyuki Tomino](https://anilist.co/staff/97337/Yoshiyuki-Tomino)'s praise, who acted as the chief judge. After Mind Game Yuasa spent several years at [MADHOUSE](https://anilist.co/studio/11/MADHOUSE) working on various projects. In 2013, he founded [Science SARU](https://anilist.co/studio/6145/Science-SARU) alongside his close affiliate [Eun-Yeong Choi](https://anilist.co/staff/115088/EunYeong-Choi).

On March 25, 2020 it was announced Yuasa stepped down as the CEO of Science SARU. He would work there as director until the completion of his latest Movie, [Inu-Oh](https://anilist.co/anime/109928/InuOh/), and would later cease any affiliation with the studio.

On February 17, 2025 it was announced that Yuasa would launch of his own animation studio, ame pippin. Their debut project would be the film [Daisy's Life](https://anilist.co/anime/190574/Hinagiku-no-Jinsei/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/masaakiyuasa)

An acclaimed anime director known for his wild, freeform style. 

After graduating from the Kyushu Sangyo University's Faculty of Arts in 1987 he joined studio [Ajia-do](https://anilist.co/studio/30/Ajiado), initially as in-betweener but rapidly moving to key animation. 

In the first part of his career Yuasa established himself as an idiosyncratic creator while working on several child friendly anime, such as [Chibi Maruko-chan](https://anilist.co/anime/951/Chibi-Marukochan/) and [Doraemon](https://anilist.co/anime/2677/Doraemon-Nobitas-Animal-Planet/), but especially on [Crayon Shin-chan](https://anilist.co/anime/966/Shin-Chan/), a project he was involved with for most of the '90s.

This OVA was an important outing of the '90s, uniting many veteran artists and talented newcomers. 

He debuted as director on [Mind Game](https://anilist.co/anime/875/Mind-Game/), an abstract piece combining animation and live-action footage, winning the 2004 Japan Media Arts Festival (overcoming even Hayao Miyazaki's [Howl's Moving Castle](https://anilist.co/anime/431/Howls-Moving-Castle/)), and earning [Yoshiyuki Tomino](https://anilist.co/staff/97337/Yoshiyuki-Tomino)'s praise, who acted as the chief judge. After Mind Game Yuasa spent several years at [MADHOUSE](https://anilist.co/studio/11/MADHOUSE) working on various projects. In 2013, he founded [Science SARU](https://anilist.co/studio/6145/Science-SARU) alongside his close affiliate [Eun-Yeong Choi](https://anilist.co/staff/115088/EunYeong-Choi).

On March 25, 2020 it was announced Yuasa stepped down as the CEO of Science SARU. He would work there as director until the completion of his latest Movie, [Inu-Oh](https://anilist.co/anime/109928/InuOh/), and would later cease any affiliation with the studio.

On February 17, 2025 it was announced that Yuasa would launch of his own animation studio, ame pippin. Their debut project would be the film [Daisy's Life](https://anilist.co/anime/190574/Hinagiku-no-Jinsei/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/747930872179875840)

A pioneer in the field of realist animation, and then digital processing.

Debuted uncredited as an in-betweneer on [Zeta Gundam](https://anilist.co/anime/85/). He made his initial splash in [Gundam 0080: War in the Pocket](https://anilist.co/anime/82/), and continued to develop his approach to animation which he calls "full limited," which eliminated the pose-to-pose feel of conventional keyframe animation. His characteristic animation can be seen in [Ghost in the Shell](https://anilist.co/anime/43/) and [End of Evangelion](https://anilist.co/anime/32/).

In [Blood: The Last Vampire](https://anilist.co/anime/405/), Iso experimented with digital processing of his hand-drawn fire effects, elevating it to uncanny realism. Iso then got his first taste of directing in [RahXephon](https://anilist.co/anime/165/) episode 15, which he largely animated and also digitally processed himself.

His animation sensibilities, process innovations, experience in multiple levels of anime production, and interest in technology culminated in the 2007 sci-fi series, [Dennou Coil](https://anilist.co/anime/2164/), his veritable brainchild. During its production, there was a rumored falling-out with key staff. For the next several years, Iso would quietly animate under the pseudonym Mikio Odagawa.

Took part as a key animator on Quentin Tarantino's "Kill Bill: Vol. 1" in 2003.

In 2018, he announced his retirement as an animator to focus exclusively on directing.
Originating from [Studio Deen](https://anilist.co/studio/37/) where he studied under [Atsuko Nakajima](https://anilist.co/staff/102141/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E5%B2%B8%E7%94%B0%E9%9A%86%E5%AE%8F)

Takahiro Kishida is an animator and renown character designer.

Kishida's designs are well received by animators and attract talent into shows easily. He is also praised for his shot composition skills and copies of his layouts are widely distributed in the industry as drawing reference. Nowadays he is mostly only credited for character design in the shows he participates in, but in reality he works as an animation director uncredited quite often. He rarely heavily corrects the key animator's cuts, strongly believing that the animators' distinctiveness should be noticeable.

Noted for his designs on shows like [Haikyuu](https://anilist.co/anime/20464/), [Serial Experiments Lain](https://anilist.co/anime/339/), [Madoka Magica](https://anilist.co/anime/9756/), [Baccano](https://anilist.co/anime/2251/) and more.

[Website](http://www.ike-yoshihiro.com/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/ikeyoshihiro)

Yoshihiro Ike is a Japanese composer, music arranger, and bassist. He is best known for scoring and composing music for movies, TV dramas, Anime and video games and has worked on more than 100 titles in the last 20 years.

His debut anime title, [Blood: The Last Vampire](https://anilist.co/anime/405/), was nominated for the 2000 UK Music Awards under the soundtrack category, and subsequently awarded the top prize at the Japan Media Arts Festival in 2001 by the Agency for Cultural affairs. In 2006, his score for [Kamichu!](https://anilist.co/anime/489/) received an Excellence Prize at the 2005 Japan Media Arts Festival. In 2018, Shadowverse original soundtracks became the highest-ranking album on iTunes, surpassing Shallow by Lady Gaga.

(Source: Wikipedia)
Freelance. Close friends with [Takahiro Kishida](https://anilist.co/staff/101403/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/235154812) | [Pixiv](https://www.pixiv.net/en/users/30949)

Started out as amateur gif animator before turning professional. He initially failed an examination test for [Gainax](https://anilist.co/studio/6/) but was later scouted by the late [Osamu Kobayashi](https://anilist.co/staff/100406/) for [Beck](https://anilist.co/anime/57/). There he met noted animators [Norio Matsumoto](https://anilist.co/staff/100991/) and [Satoru Utsunomiya](https://anilist.co/staff/101489/), the former which he would work with on numerous occasions afterwards.

His breakthrough as an animator was on [Noein](https://anilist.co/anime/584/), a series directed by [Kazuki Akane](https://anilist.co/staff/102416/). The 12th episode was highly regarded by animation fans and other animators for the given display by him and Matsumoto. He would later also serve as a character designer on [Birdy the Mighty: Decode](https://anilist.co/anime/3974/), another series directed by Akane.

His dedication for animation could also be seen on [The Girl Who Leapt Through Time](https://anilist.co/anime/2236/), for which he animated a minute-long scene of the main character running down a street. He went on the actual street in Tokyo to film himself for reference footage for the cut.
Notable directorial works include [Kamichu!](https://anilist.co/anime/489/), [Welcome to the Space Show](https://anilist.co/anime/8115/) and [Magi](https://anilist.co/anime/14513/).
Notable directorial works include [Kamichu!](https://anilist.co/anime/489/), [Welcome to the Space Show](https://anilist.co/anime/8115/) and [Magi](https://anilist.co/anime/14513/).

Originating from Eagle Nest. Currently freelance.

Tanaka first drew attention for the wild and imaginative fight sequences in Precure [Max Heart](https://anilist.co/anime/1929/) and [Splash Star](https://anilist.co/anime/1534/). Following this he expanded his scope and took up work on productions all around the industry, showing that fights aren't everything he can do. His variety on running sequences, often showing an effiminate touch, as well as the particular attention to hair, down to all little strains and often involving a hairdo having a life of its own, are some of Tanaka's most outstanding feats.

__Non-anime credits:__
~!
- Chief Animator, Animation Character Design, Storyboard, Director, Animation Director, Key Animation for "BlazBlue: Calamity Trigger (OP)" (video game, 2008)
- Key Animation for "Disgaea D2: A Brighter Darkness (OP)" (video game, 2013)
- Key Animation for "livetune adding Fukase (from SEKAI NO OWARI) 「Take Your Way」" (music video, 2013)
- Key Animation for "Rurouni Kenshin: Meiji Kenkaku Romantan Saisen (OP)" (video game, 2011)
- Key Animation for "Valkyria Chronicles III" (video game, 2011)!~
Originating from [Gainax](https://anilist.co/studio/6/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E6%9D%91%E6%9C%A8%E9%9D%96)

Yasushi Muraki is an animator and an occasional director affiliated with [Bones](https://anilist.co/studio/4/).

Admired [Ichirou Itano](https://anilist.co/staff/103268/) and [Masami Oobari](https://anilist.co/staff/100660/), and became an animator. He is skilled in mechanical and action animation, and is one of three animators alongside [Hideaki Anno](https://anilist.co/staff/100111/) and [Masami Gotou](https://anilist.co/staff/129865/) who are said to have fully mastered the "Itano Circus" drawing technique. He was invited to join the production of [Eureka Seven](https://anilist.co/anime/237/) by [Kenichi Yoshida](https://anilist.co/staff/103498/), who was in charge of character designs and became the special effects director of the series, fully demonstrating his skills.

(Source: Wikipedia)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/岡真里子)

Originating from Studio Live. Notable works as a character designer include [Jigoku Shoujo](https://anilist.co/anime/228/), [Ghost Hound](https://anilist.co/anime/2596/) and [Nurarihyon no Mago](https://anilist.co/anime/7592/). Close friends with [Hiroshi Watanabe](https://anilist.co/staff/101189/), and often designs the characters for the shows which he directs.
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/Shinjukueyes)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/795583350)

Currently a freelancer with deep ties to [CloverWorks](https://anilist.co/studio/6222/CloverWorks).

He is close friends with [Yasuomi Umetsu](https://anilist.co/staff/101583/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/795583350)

Currently a freelancer with deep ties to [CloverWorks](https://anilist.co/studio/6222/CloverWorks).

He is close friends with [Yasuomi Umetsu](https://anilist.co/staff/101583/).

Besame Mucho is a collective pseudonym of [Kouji Masunari](https://anilist.co/staff/103187/), [Hideyuki Kurata](https://anilist.co/staff/96967/) and [Tomonori Ochikoshi](https://anilist.co/staff/147463/).
Representative director of [Aniplex](https://anilist.co/studio/17/). Board Director at [CloverWorks](https://anilist.co/studio/6222/CloverWorks).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/johnsama) | [Pixiv](https://www.pixiv.net/en/users/75255)

Noted for his work in the [Sword Art Online](https://anilist.co/anime/11757/) franchise.

Married to fellow animator [Haruko Iizuka](https://anilist.co/staff/105678/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/193795545)

Originating from [J.C. Staff](https://anilist.co/studio/7/).
[Twitter](http://twitter.com/i/user/128364216)
